title: Romans Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 9.

questions.question: According to Romans 9:3, what did Paul say he could wish for himself?
options: That he were accursed from Christ for his brethren
That he had great joy and peace
That he might see the promised land
That he were blessed above all
questions.correctAnswer: That he were accursed from Christ for his brethren
questions.explanation: Romans 9:3 states Paul could wish that he himself were accursed from Christ for his brethren.

questions.question: Who are described as having the adoption, glory, covenants, law, service of God, and promises in Romans 9:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Israelites
questions.explanation: Romans 9:4 explains that these privileges belong to the Israelites.

questions.question: According to Romans 9:7, who is the seed of Abraham through whom the children are called?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaac
questions.explanation: Romans 9:7 states that in Isaac shall thy seed be called.

questions.question: In Romans 9:8, who are counted as the children of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Children of the promise
questions.explanation: Romans 9:8 clarifies that the children of the promise are counted for the seed, not the children of the flesh.

questions.question: What did God say to Moses about showing mercy according to Romans 9:15?
options: I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy
I will bless those who follow me
I will save only the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy
questions.explanation: Romans 9:15 quotes God saying He will have mercy on whom He will have mercy.

questions.question: Romans 9:17 mentions Pharaoh. What was the purpose of raising him up?
options: To show God's power and declare His name
To lead Israel out of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To show God's power and declare His name
questions.explanation: Romans 9:17 states that God raised up Pharaoh to show His power and declare His name throughout the earth.

questions.question: In Romans 9:21, who is compared to the potter in control of the clay?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Romans 9:21 compares God to the potter who has power over the clay to make vessels for honor or dishonor.

questions.question: According to Romans 9:23, what did God prepare beforehand for the vessels of mercy?
questions.correctAnswer: Glory
questions.explanation: Romans 9:23 says God prepared glory beforehand for the vessels of mercy.

questions.question: In Romans 9:24, who are called by God besides the Jews?
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles
questions.explanation: Romans 9:24 explains that God has called not only Jews but also Gentiles.

questions.question: What does Romans 9:27 say about the number of the children of Israel and salvation?
options: Though many, a remnant shall be saved
Only the elders will be saved
questions.correctAnswer: Though many, a remnant shall be saved
questions.explanation: Romans 9:27 states that though the children of Israel are as the sand of the sea, a remnant shall be saved.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 9:14 asks if there is unrighteousness with God and rejects that idea.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 9:14 asks if there is unrighteousness with God and answers 'God forbid,' rejecting the idea.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 9:31 says Israel attained righteousness by following the law.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 9:31 states Israel did not attain righteousness by following the law.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 9:19 questions why God finds fault if no one can resist His will.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 9:19 contains the question about why God finds fault if no one resists His will.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Romans 9:13: 'Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: hated
questions.explanation: Romans 9:13 says, 'Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Romans 9:33: 'Behold, I lay in Sion a stumblingstone and rock of offence: and whosoever ______ on him shall not be ashamed.'
questions.correctAnswer: believeth
questions.explanation: Romans 9:33 states, 'whosoever believeth on him shall not be ashamed.'

medium.title: Romans Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of discouragement and sorrow over the spiritual state of their loved ones. Based on Romans 9:1-3, what biblical truth would you share about intercessory love and sacrifice?
options: Paul expresses deep sorrow and would even wish to be accursed for his brethren.
Paul advises to ignore such feelings and focus only on personal faith.
Paul says that sorrow over others’ sin is unnecessary because God’s plan is fixed.
Paul encourages believers to isolate themselves from unbelievers.
questions.correctAnswer: Paul expresses deep sorrow and would even wish to be accursed for his brethren.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:1-3 shows Paul’s great heaviness and sorrow for his kinsmen according to the flesh, even wishing to be accursed for their sake. This teaches the virtue of intercessory love and heartfelt prayer for others.

questions.question: How does Romans 9:6-8 teach us about the nature of true spiritual identity and faith in God's promises?
options: Not all who are physically descended from Israel are true children of God; children of the promise are counted as the seed.
Being born into a religious family guarantees salvation.
Physical descent from Abraham is the primary mark of God's people.
Faith is irrelevant compared to works of the law.
questions.correctAnswer: Not all who are physically descended from Israel are true children of God; children of the promise are counted as the seed.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:6-8 highlights that true spiritual identity is not based on fleshly descent but on being children of the promise, emphasizing faith and God's election over heritage.

questions.question: A believer questions why God shows mercy to some and not to others. According to Romans 9:14-16, how should we understand God's mercy and justice?
options: God has mercy on whom He chooses, and it is not based on human will or effort.
God’s mercy is earned by good works.
God’s justice is flawed and unfair.
Mercy is given only to those who deserve it.
questions.correctAnswer: God has mercy on whom He chooses, and it is not based on human will or effort.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:14-16 explains that God's mercy is sovereign and not dependent on human will or running, showing that His justice is perfect and beyond human judgment.

questions.question: How does the metaphor of the potter and clay in Romans 9:20-21 teach humility and submission to God's will in daily life?
options: We should accept God’s sovereign authority over our lives without dispute.
We have the right to question God’s decisions about us.
We can demand God make us as we desire.
God is powerless to shape our lives.
questions.correctAnswer: We should accept God’s sovereign authority over our lives without dispute.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:20-21 teaches that just as the potter has authority over the clay, God has sovereign power over His creation, encouraging believers to humbly accept His will.

questions.question: A Christian facing trials wonders why God allows hardship for some and shows mercy to others. Based on Romans 9:22-23, what biblical truth about God's purposes can encourage perseverance?
options: God endures vessels of wrath to show His power and patience and prepares vessels of mercy for glory.
God punishes people arbitrarily without purpose.
Suffering means God has rejected a person permanently.
questions.correctAnswer: God endures vessels of wrath to show His power and patience and prepares vessels of mercy for glory.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:22-23 reveals that God’s longsuffering with some demonstrates His power and justice, while He also prepares others for mercy and glory, giving believers hope amid trials.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 9:24, God’s call extends only to the Jewish people and excludes the Gentiles.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 9:24 states that God calls not only Jews but also Gentiles, showing His inclusive mercy and the extension of salvation to all who believe.

questions.question: How does Romans 9:25-26 illustrate God's ability to transform relationships and identity in the life of believers, encouraging those feeling unworthy?
options: God calls those who were not His people to become His beloved and children of the living God.
Only those born into God's covenant are His people.
God’s call is limited to a specific ethnic group.
Once rejected, a person cannot become part of God’s people.
questions.correctAnswer: God calls those who were not His people to become His beloved and children of the living God.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:25-26 uses Hosea’s prophecy to show God’s power to call outsiders into His family, offering hope and new identity to believers.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they feel they do not measure up to the law. Based on Romans 9:30-31, what biblical truth about righteousness by faith would you share?
options: Gentiles attained righteousness through faith, while Israel sought it by works and did not attain it.
Righteousness can only be earned by strict law-keeping.
Faith is unnecessary if one follows the law perfectly.
Both Gentiles and Jews attain righteousness by works.
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles attained righteousness through faith, while Israel sought it by works and did not attain it.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:30-31 contrasts righteousness by faith with seeking it through the law, teaching that faith is the true path to righteousness.

questions.question: How does Romans 9:32-33 explain the reason some stumble spiritually, and what does it teach about faith and obedience?
options: They stumble because they seek righteousness by works instead of faith, rejecting Christ as the cornerstone.
Stumbling is due to lack of knowledge only.
Everyone will stumble regardless of faith.
Obedience to the law without faith guarantees righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: They stumble because they seek righteousness by works instead of faith, rejecting Christ as the cornerstone.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:32-33 explains that rejecting faith in Christ, the stumbling stone, leads to spiritual failure, underscoring the need for faith and trust in God’s provision.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 9:13 teaches that God’s love and hatred toward Jacob and Esau were based on their personal actions and merits.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 9:13 shows God’s sovereign choice in loving Jacob and hating Esau before their works, emphasizing election by God’s will, not human merit.

questions.question: In light of Romans 9:17, how can believers understand God’s use of difficult people or circumstances in their lives?
options: God raises up certain people, like Pharaoh, to demonstrate His power and declare His name.
Difficult people are sent to punish us without purpose.
God abandons believers when difficulties arise.
questions.correctAnswer: God raises up certain people, like Pharaoh, to demonstrate His power and declare His name.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:17 teaches that God sovereignly uses even opposition to showcase His power and glory, encouraging believers to trust Him in trials.

questions.question: How does Romans 9:15 help us pray with humility regarding who receives God’s mercy?
options: We acknowledge that God shows mercy according to His own will, not ours.
We can demand God show mercy only to us.
Mercy is a right earned by prayer volume.
God’s mercy is random and unpredictable.
questions.correctAnswer: We acknowledge that God shows mercy according to His own will, not ours.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:15 reminds us that mercy is sovereignly granted by God, teaching humility and trust in His perfect judgment in prayer.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 9:11 says, "(For the children being not yet born, neither having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to ___ might stand, not of works, but of him that calleth;)"
questions.correctAnswer: election
questions.explanation: Romans 9:11 explains that God’s purpose according to election stands independent of works, emphasizing divine choice and calling.

questions.question: According to Romans 9:4-5, what spiritual blessings pertain to the Israelites, and how does this encourage believers about God's faithfulness?
options: Adoption, glory, covenants, law, service of God, promises, and Christ’s human lineage.
questions.correctAnswer: Adoption, glory, covenants, law, service of God, promises, and Christ’s human lineage.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:4-5 lists the spiritual privileges of Israel, showing God’s faithfulness to His promises and encouraging believers to trust His covenantal plan.

questions.question: A believer is confused about God’s justice when some are hardened. According to Romans 9:18-19, what response does Paul give to those questioning God’s fairness?
options: God has mercy on whom He wills and hardens whom He wills; humans should not question God's decisions.
God is unjust and should be challenged.
Everyone is hardened equally without mercy.
God’s decisions are based on popularity.
questions.correctAnswer: God has mercy on whom He wills and hardens whom He wills; humans should not question God's decisions.
questions.explanation: Romans 9:18-19 teaches God’s sovereign choice in mercy and hardening, and that humans should humbly accept His will rather than resist or question it.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 9.

questions.question: In Romans 9, Paul expresses a deep sorrow for his kinsmen according to the flesh. What does he say he could wish regarding himself for their sake?
options: That he were accursed from Christ
That he might be exalted above them
That he might inherit the promises
That he might become a Gentile
questions.correctAnswer: That he were accursed from Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 9:3 shows Paul's profound love and sacrifice, as he states he could wish to be accursed from Christ for his brethren, highlighting his earnest intercession.

questions.question: According to Romans 9, who are considered the true children of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Children of the promise
questions.explanation: Romans 9:8 clarifies that not all who are children of the flesh are children of God, but those who are children of the promise are counted as the seed, emphasizing spiritual lineage over physical descent.

questions.question: What Old Testament figure is quoted in Romans 9:13 to illustrate God's sovereign election?
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and Esau
questions.explanation: Romans 9:13 quotes Malachi 1:2-3, where God says, 'Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated,' demonstrating divine election independent of works.

questions.question: In Romans 9, Paul cites God's words to Moses about mercy. What does God declare about showing mercy and compassion?
options: He will have mercy on whom He will have mercy
Mercy is given to those who obey the law
Compassion is earned by good works
questions.correctAnswer: He will have mercy on whom He will have mercy
questions.explanation: Romans 9:15 quotes Exodus 33:19, emphasizing God's sovereign freedom to grant mercy and compassion according to His will, not human merit.

questions.question: How does Romans 9 describe the role of human will and effort in God's mercy?
options: It is not of him that willeth nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy
It depends on human effort and desire
It is granted based on lineage
questions.correctAnswer: It is not of him that willeth nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy
questions.explanation: Romans 9:16 teaches that mercy is solely dependent on God's choice rather than human desire or action, highlighting divine sovereignty.

questions.question: Which Pharaoh is mentioned in Romans 9 as an example of God raising someone up to demonstrate His power?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh of the Exodus
questions.explanation: Romans 9:17 references the Pharaoh of Exodus, whom God raised up to display His power and proclaim His name throughout the earth.

questions.question: What analogy does Paul use in Romans 9 to describe God's authority over creation and divine decisions about mercy and hardening?
questions.correctAnswer: The potter and the clay
questions.explanation: Romans 9:21 uses the imagery of a potter having authority over clay to illustrate God's right to shape destinies, including vessels for honor and dishonor.

questions.question: In Romans 9, what is the purpose of God enduring with longsuffering the vessels of wrath, according to Paul?
options: To make known His wrath and power
To show partiality to Israel only
To reward works of the law
questions.correctAnswer: To make known His wrath and power
questions.explanation: Romans 9:22 explains that God's endurance of vessels of wrath serves to display His wrath and power, contrasting with vessels of mercy.

questions.question: Romans 9:24 states that God has called not only Jews but also which other group?
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles
questions.explanation: Romans 9:24 emphasizes the inclusion of Gentiles in God's call, highlighting the expansion of salvation beyond ethnic Israel.

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophet's words are cited in Romans 9:25-26 to show God's calling of those not previously His people?
questions.correctAnswer: Osee (Hosea)
questions.explanation: Romans 9:25-26 quotes Hosea 2:23 and 1:10, illustrating God's promise to call those not previously His people 'children of the living God.'

questions.question: According to Romans 9, what will happen to the vast number of Israel's descendants?
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant will be saved
questions.explanation: Romans 9:27 cites Isaiah to affirm that though Israel's descendants are numerous, only a remnant will be saved, pointing to selective salvation.

questions.question: What Old Testament event is alluded to in Romans 9:29 to illustrate God's preservation of a faithful seed?
options: The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
The crossing of the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
questions.explanation: Romans 9:29 references Isaiah 1:9, comparing Israel's preservation to the remnant spared from Sodom and Gomorrah's destruction.

questions.question: What is described as the 'stumblingstone' in Romans 9, causing Israel to stumble because they sought righteousness by works rather than faith?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 9:32-33 explains that Christ is the stumblingstone and rock of offense, causing Israel's failure as they sought righteousness through the law instead of faith.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 9 teaches that God's election is based on human works and effort.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 9:11 states that God's purpose according to election stands not by works but by His calling, affirming divine sovereignty over human merit.

questions.question: According to Romans 9, what is the relationship between following the law and attaining righteousness for Israel?
options: Israel did not attain righteousness by following the law
Israel attained righteousness perfectly by the law
The law was irrelevant to righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Israel did not attain righteousness by following the law
questions.explanation: Romans 9:31 teaches that Israel, pursuing the law of righteousness, did not attain it because they sought it by works rather than faith.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 9:1, what bears witness with Paul's conscience in declaring the truth?
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Romans 9:1 states that Paul's conscience bears him witness in the Holy Ghost, affirming the divine assurance of his truthfulness. This aligns with Hebrews 10:15 and John 14:26, where the Holy Spirit is described as the witness and teacher of truth.

questions.question: What does Paul express he could wish for himself for the sake of his brethren according to the flesh in Romans 9:3?
options: To be a leader among Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: To be accursed from Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 9:3 reveals Paul's deep sorrow that he could wish to be accursed from Christ for his kinsmen. This sacrificial love reflects Christ's own atonement (Galatians 2:20) and the apostolic commitment to the salvation of Israel (Romans 10:1).

questions.question: Which of the following privileges belong to the Israelites as listed in Romans 9:4?
options: Adoption, glory, covenants, law, service of God, and promises
questions.correctAnswer: Adoption, glory, covenants, law, service of God, and promises
questions.explanation: Romans 9:4 enumerates the spiritual privileges given to Israelites: adoption, glory, covenants, law, service of God, and promises. These underline God's covenantal faithfulness (Genesis 17:7, Exodus 19:5-6) and the unique role of Israel in salvation history (Deuteronomy 7:6).

questions.question: What does Paul mean when he says 'They are not all Israel, which are of Israel' in Romans 9:6?
options: Not all physical descendants of Israel are true children of God
Israel is a political nation only
Only those who follow the law are Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Not all physical descendants of Israel are true children of God
questions.explanation: Romans 9:6 teaches that physical descent does not guarantee spiritual inheritance; true Israel are those who belong by promise (Galatians 6:16, Jeremiah 31:33). This distinction emphasizes God's sovereign election (Isaiah 10:22-23).

questions.question: In Romans 9:8, who are considered the true children of God?
questions.correctAnswer: The children of the promise
questions.explanation: Romans 9:8 clarifies that true children of God are those born according to promise, not merely by natural descent. This is consistent with Galatians 4:28 and Hebrews 11:11, emphasizing faith and God's promise over fleshly lineage.

questions.question: What divine principle is explained in Romans 9:11 regarding God's election?
options: It is based on God's purpose and not on works
It is based on cultural heritage
questions.correctAnswer: It is based on God's purpose and not on works
questions.explanation: Romans 9:11 states that God's election is based on His purpose, not on human works. This doctrine aligns with Ephesians 1:4-5 and John 6:44, illustrating God's sovereign grace in salvation.

questions.question: How does Romans 9:13 describe God's relationship to Jacob and Esau?
options: Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated
questions.explanation: Romans 9:13 quotes Malachi 1:2-3 to show God's sovereign election, loving Jacob and hating Esau, symbolizing God's freedom in choosing His purposes (Deuteronomy 7:7-8, Malachi 1:2-3).

questions.question: According to Romans 9:15, what does God say to Moses about mercy and compassion?
options: I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and compassion on whom I will have compassion
questions.correctAnswer: I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and compassion on whom I will have compassion
questions.explanation: Romans 9:15 cites Exodus 33:19, emphasizing God's sovereign choice in mercy and compassion, consistent with His justice and grace (Psalm 103:8, Lamentations 3:22-23).

questions.question: What is the teaching of Romans 9:16 about the source of mercy?
options: Mercy comes from God, not from human will or effort
Mercy is earned by good deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy comes from God, not from human will or effort
questions.explanation: Romans 9:16 teaches that mercy is from God alone, not dependent on human willing or running. This is consistent with John 1:13 and Titus 3:5, affirming salvation by grace.

questions.question: What purpose did God have in raising up Pharaoh according to Romans 9:17?
options: To show His power and declare His name throughout the earth
questions.correctAnswer: To show His power and declare His name throughout the earth
questions.explanation: Romans 9:17 reveals God's sovereign use of Pharaoh to manifest His power and reveal His name globally, paralleling Exodus 9:16 and demonstrating God's ultimate control over human history.

questions.question: According to Romans 9:21, who has authority over the vessels made for honor and dishonor?
questions.correctAnswer: The potter over the clay
questions.explanation: Romans 9:21 uses the metaphor of the potter's authority over clay to illustrate God's sovereign right to shape His creation, consistent with Jeremiah 18:6 and Isaiah 64:8.

questions.question: What reason does Romans 9:22 give for God enduring 'vessels of wrath' with much longsuffering?
options: To show His wrath and make His power known
questions.correctAnswer: To show His wrath and make His power known
questions.explanation: Romans 9:22 explains God's patience with vessels of wrath serves to display His wrath and manifest His power, reflecting divine justice and mercy also seen in Exodus 34:6-7 and Psalm 103:8.

questions.question: Who, besides the Jews, are called by God according to Romans 9:24?
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Romans 9:24 states that God calls not only Jews but also Gentiles, emphasizing the inclusion of all nations into His redemptive plan, consistent with Isaiah 56:6-7 and Acts 10:34-35.

questions.question: What prophecy from Hosea is cited in Romans 9:25-26 about God's people?
options: I will call those who were not my people, my people
questions.correctAnswer: I will call those who were not my people, my people
questions.explanation: Romans 9:25-26 quotes Hosea 2:23 and 1:10, indicating God's promise to adopt those previously not His people, fulfilling His covenant faithfulness and extending salvation beyond Israel.

questions.question: According to Romans 9:30-31, why did the Gentiles attain righteousness, but Israel did not?
options: Gentiles attained righteousness by faith, Israel sought it by works of the law
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles attained righteousness by faith, Israel sought it by works of the law
questions.explanation: Romans 9:30-31 contrasts righteousness attained by faith (Gentiles) with Israel's pursuit by law works, aligning with Galatians 3:11 and Psalm 143:2, emphasizing justification by faith.
